review_title: Biology Lab Manager at Purdue University
job_title: Lab Manager in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Purdue University, like many universities, allows certain employees a flexible schedule.  You can essentially determine the hours you work as long as you can get your work done and your supervisor doesn't mind.  You do not need to work more than 40 hours a week if you aren't a professor.  It's also a cheap area to live- very affordable.  Purdue is always changing- with the influx of new students each year, any position you hold where you get to interact with them will be different year to year, even if your duties remain the same.  It's nice to get to work with new people!
cons: The pay isn't very good, and they don't get rid of people who aren't good at their jobs.  Salary increases are very small, even for the top performers.  It can be frustrating if the students you work with have no respect for their jobs and don't care about doing research.  Certain professors at Purdue can be very lax about disciplining their students who are cheating or making up their data, and just pass the problem onto the next person who needs to deal with them.  I actually encountered a professor who didn't fail anyone because they didn't want to have to deal with the bad students again.

review_title: A great University to grow and develop as an engineering student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
Many of these pros are very specific to your advisor and program, however in my experience:
1. Many renowned faculty to study under 
2. Many intelligent students to learn from
3. Opportunities to travel to conferences
4. Low cost of living
5. The people of Indiana and the midwest are very nice
6. Great graduate classes 
7. Amazing reputation of the University when finally seeking a job
8. Great engineering facilities on the whole
cons:
Many of these consare very specific to your advisor and program, however in my experience:
1. Conservative nature of the campus and faculty can sometimes lead to impersonal relations with the advisor
2. Winter weather
3. The pay is on the scale of the cost of living, but let's face it, grad student pay is never more than enough to scrape by on
4. The social options in the immediate area are sometimes lacking
5. The academic culture as a whole...the individualism of research can lead to competitiveness among peers that is unproductive and sometimes nasty.  This is not specific to Purdue, I presume.

job_title: Instructor in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
I taught a freshman engineering class for two semester. I also taught a lab for sophomore for two semester. So, in general I have four semester of teaching experience.

It is a great place to learn. It gave me enough time to excel the course material while teaching it. 

It also gave me an opportunity to interact and manage students from different culture and different countries. That's a great leadership experience. 

Sometimes I had a Teaching assistant or lab assistant for me. I had to manage him which was an awesome experience. Like how to keep your TA happy and bring the best out of him.

I meet one nerdy student ( who knows course material better than me ) every student from whom I can learn. Some of them became my good friends and I hope they will be my friends for the lifetime.

You can design class on your own as far as you cover the course material. You can go at your own pace.
cons: Relatively low salary without any compensation in Tuition fees and health benefits.

review_title: Great workplace - France A. Córdova Recreational Sports Center
job_title: CPR/First Aid Instructor in West Lafayette, IN
pros: They have a great work and school balance - work schedule is flexible to what you need to do. It is a great environment to be in, everyone is willing to help with what needs to be done. There are many different oppurtunties to advance and work in different areas. They offer jobs such as Facility Attendant, Entry, Personal Trainer, Fitness Consultant, Lifeguard, Member Services, and many others. I worked with many of the upper management and they have been open to new suggestions about new improvements or ideas that can help improve a certain area, i.e. CPR and First Aid, Aquatic Center - Swim Meets, expansion of programs into the community
cons: The compensation is low and there are not many hours to work since there are so many employees. Some areas had trouble communicating - not all the areas talk with each other about what events are happening. Different areas have a different environment, one position is relaxed and easygoing with the job while another position can be constantly stressed and not wanting to be at work.

review_title: A positive, friendly place that values talent
job_title: Continuing Lecturer in West Lafayette, IN
pros: An extremely well-run university that makes sense in its administration and has high academic standards.  Amazing benefits! Great facilities.  Undergraduates mainly hardworking and interested in their education, although there are exceptions.  All policies etc. are online and available without a paywall or registration gateway.  They value their faculty highly and it shows. Technology advances are well-thought-out.  Decent, but not stellar, pay.
cons: Sometimes it seems as if there is a big middle-management layer whose exact responsibilities are hard to fathom.  Administrative technology systems are desperate for integration, but they are working on that.  The Purdue/IU rivalry is unfriendly and borders on outright hatred, which is difficult culturally for someone like me with strong loyalties to both schools--I feel I have to hide my IU pride here.

review_title: Great university for research and connections, but a bureaucratic nightmare inside.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: An engineering graduate degree at Purdue will place you at a competative advantage when compared to your peers at other institutions. The network of contacts you will make will give you a good chance at a good job even while the economy is turning south. Also, the work here is as hands on as you want to make it; you can truly be involved in the design, development, testing, and evaluation of your own project while a Master's student.
cons: The biggest downside of working at Purdue is the bureaucracy. Whether it comes in the form of walking between three different buildings on opposite sides of campus to verify that you're registered for classes or only being allowed to visit one in-network set of doctors that are on campus to get health screenings, it sometimes seems impossible to get anything accomplished.

review_title: A great way to gain experience but a hard job
job_title: Resident Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
They pay in state tuition and your room and board. 
Training can be tedious but parts of it will totally prepare you for the position. 
You can build a great community and with the right staff you can have a wonderful experience.
It is wonderful to graduate with much less debt than I was anticipating.
cons:
Paying in-state tuition is not necessarily enough. You are on "duty" four nights a week but any time they can call you back to deal with a situation. I have been called on several occasions to come back on several occasions to deal with roommate conflicts. 
You are with your staff constantly, so it can get difficult working with them.
It is very difficult to have a work-life balance. You work where you live so it's hard to separate work from your personal life.
You MUST be good at time management (or you will be by the time you're done) or your grades will suffer. Many first year RA's will drop out at semester because they can't handle it.

job_title: Faculty in Hammond, IN
pros: There are many good people working at PUC: they're smart, upbeat, and enthusiastic, with lots of energy. Many students are first-generation college students and are people trying to change the trajectory of their and their families' lives. Because of this, there's tremendous opportunity to help people and to make a difference in their lives.
cons: Unfortunately, the school suffers from severe morale problems. There have been massive cutbacks and cutting of resources, to the point that they have all but stopped doing basic things like collecting garbage from offices and classrooms. Many teaching positions have been axed (as well, many people have fled to other institutions or taken early retirement) as management and administration continues to balloon in size. Expectations, evaluation, and promotion decisions are massively uneven and have little to do with merit.

job_title: IT Professional in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Great entry level work. Lots of PTO.  Low stress I guess?
cons: A bunch of employees lack motivation.  Benefits  are being stripped. Raises are under inflation. Constantly spammed to donate back (I cannot stress how constant it seems).

review_title: Overworked, Underpaid, and POOR leadership can sum up Purdue Calumet!

Staff are underpaid, so people tend to use this place as a launching pad for their career, upper management realizes this and seem's to push talent away before they walk away. New staff is always hit and miss because they won't pay the talented people what they are worth.

 Insurance is extremely expensive.

There is not a lot of opportunity for growth, they do not promote within. 

Raises are an insult, tax rates increase by more than annual raises

review_title: Great place to work in a staff role if you're not looking to advance
job_title: Graduate Programs Director in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The notoriety and credibility of the university makes a statement on your resume and within your career development. In the right position, and working for the right supervisor, you can experience neat opportunities for professional development and creativity in project development. The staff fee remit makes it possible to further your education or put your kids through college at a great discount.
cons: For people in staff positions working in academic areas, your position is considered a terminal position. The university does not work on succession planning for staff or recognize rising stars who should have opportunity to move into more challenging roles. Plan to stay in your position until you find another university job you'd like to apply for and then prepare to be treated as if you're an outsider during the hiring process, rather than a great employee whose expanding skills and experience should be better utilized in a different role.

review_title: Because of the large academic, interdisciplinary community, I have been successful in my research.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The college community is very safe, diverse, moderate politically, and educated well-above average, especially for Indiana.  Purdue is always expanding, but perhaps, they should spend more money on providing more money for research and outreach.
cons: Despite the diversity, the culture here is somewhat lacking, but if you look hard enough, you can find things to do.  Very conservative Governor Mitch Daniels will be the new president here in January, but he might be able to bring lots of money to the university.

review_title: Pnw is going Downhill fast financially.
job_title: Low Level Administrative in Hammond, IN
pros: Benefits are reasonably priced. Most employees are very good to work with.  Tuition reduction for employees. Campus is nice , they are finally upgrading rooms and will be very techy soon.
cons: Senior leadership team.  Some departments give huge raises, most do not.  If you are unlucky you will get a co worker that takes off all the time and you you have to do their work. Professors travel more than teach.  Wages are not consistent across campus.   Your salary depends on your department.  Lots of nepotism as far as the new merge of 2 campuses.  Westville administrators take care of their employees only.  We are told major deficit but spending in departments is crazy !!!  And the spending on art? Really? Millions spent. on art around campus.  Love art but this is not an art school.

job_title: in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
The work atmosphere is very laid back and low stress. 
The benefits package is good. Employees get a lot of paid time off as well as Medical, Vision, Dental.
West Lafayette is a wonderful place to raise a family with great schools - although the winters can be tough. 
Working for a university also affords a lot of opportunities to learn by taking courses etc. 
There are some cutting edge projects going on at Purdue so getting involved in one or more of them can provide opportunities to increase knowledge. 
Being able to cheer for the Boilermaker teams is also a big plus.
cons:
Since Purdue is an educational institution the culture is one where educational degrees are put on a mantle when compared to professional experience. 
To really advance to any meaningful position at Purdue requires a PhD as anything less is viewed as inferior. 
Also, most professors and managers believe any work can probably be done by Graduate assistants and do not value professionals too much.

review_title: It's OK... unless you can do better
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: It's ok to work there while you are getting your graduate degree, such as MS or PhD.  You are usually paid peanuts, but instead you get free tuition.  And Purdue University is very well recognized name among the employers.  You probably going to start on a strong foot with your first job if you have Purdue University in your resume.  Also, while working there you have a chance to interact with pretty smart and knowledgeable people.
cons: Beyond the fact that you are not paid much for positions like Research Assistant or Teaching Assistant, which is a norm for all around academia, there is only one downside to working at the Physics Department of Purdue University.  And it's a huge one.  Everybody is completely wrapped up  in the internal departmental politics.  There is no real sharing of ideas between different groups, which is not really conducive to a healthy research.

review_title: Strong Campus Life and Community; Good Pay; Increasingly humanistic environment
job_title: Resident Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The pay was great, especially for a college student. In general, you will find a good community and a lot of activity on campus. This makes it easy to get your residents involved in activities (unless they are addicted to video games). The management in the residence halls seems to be constantly changing which could be good or bad, depending on who is being moved around.
cons: Certain ideologies, which includes affirmation of things that are dishonoring to God, are becoming increasingly forced on the college population, employees and students alike. In other words, you may face some form of persecution for holding biblical values in an increasingly secular humanistic university environment.

job_title: Evening Supervisor in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Excellent place to work at while furthering your education. Decent benefits and half off tuition make this a great way to work your way through college. A good way to hone your people skills; both with customers and fellow employees. High potential for growth and opportunities to further your career, assuming you know where to look and how to network.
cons: You have to know how to work with student employees, and entrenched workers only here for the health benefits, in order to survive. Salary alone isn't that great, and you have to find how best to use the other job perks.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good university with the potential to be great. Low cost of living, decent salary, short commute if you live in the general area (~10), currently hiring more junior faculty moving the old guards out.
cons: The HHS college/school needs a new dean, one that has the experience of being a dean and one with vision and leadership skills- not one that was in a leadership position. Not the same. Although cost of living is good- younger faculty are limited with what one might expect for quality of life. Restaurants keep on closing not enough support.

review_title: Great place for students to work,  but non-teaching Professionals can probably do better elsewhere
job_title: Software Developer in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
Purdue gives me flexible hours and high pay as a student-employee; even when I only get 10hrs a week I make as much as most (non-professional) students working 20hrs or more elsewhere off-campus.

I get can easily get to work by walking and can come in between classes (I'm flextime however).  

Many of the projects I'm associated with publish work which I can show to future employers as proof of my accomplishments while a student-employee here at Purdue.
cons:
I rarely get my full 20-hours a week due to lack of work to be done (This is somewhat normal for "flex-time" student employees).  

Timecard turn-ins can be a pain if my boss leaves early or is teaching a class and I can't get his signature.

Getting paid bi-weekly can be rought sometimes.

review_title: Cheap cost of living, politics and structure of a large institution, Graduate Student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
-West Lafayette area is very cheap to live so the salary goes a long way
- There are some inspirational faculty that can serve as mentors and help navigate the bureaucracy of universities
- The starting time off (22 days/year + holidays) is great and higher than other places starting out
cons:
- As a graduate student (whether RA, GA, TA, or Fellow) you are often given the "short end of the stick" when it comes to benefits. The health insurance is good for basic needs but if you need to see any specialty doctors, good luck finding someone in-network. We get treated as "staff" when it is convenient for the university but then treated as "students" when it is convenient for them which is quite difficult
- You have to be self motivated to seek mentors and funding, although this is common of any graduate experience at a large institution

review_title: Not good for long term growth
job_title: Programmer Analyst in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
Lots of benefits, training and learning opportunities
Workload is light and work schedule can be flexible
Tuition deduction and scholarship for employees, so it is a smart move if you get a degree while you work.
Multi-culture. Foreign workers are pretty common.
cons:
1.5% to 2.5% salary increase is a joke comparing to industries.
Salary is largely dependent on the level of education not work experience. For example, if you have a Phd, it's very likely you are in the 80k - 100k range. And if you have a bachelor degree, it's 45k to 50k. Master degree splits in the middle.
Chances of promotion within 10 years of employment is next to 0%, because there are large percentage of senior employees occupying crucial positions just counting the days to retirement.
Job security largely depends on government funding not your performance.

review_title: It was hard work, but it was a rewarding summer job that I would definitely do again.
job_title: Forestry Department Field Maintenance in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
Great compensation, good people to work with, and a friendly environment.
This was an outdoors job over the summer that provided me with different tasks each day, so the job never became boring. In addition, I was able to learn how to operate machinery like tractors, chainsaws, and forklifts, and I doubt that I would have learned these on my own outside of the job. It is pretty relaxed as far as taking breaks go, since it does get extremely hot in the summer.
cons: It was definitely hard work. 8-5 every day of manual labor outside, and there is a lot to learn for those like myself who are not experienced in using heavy machinery (tractors, chainsaws, etc...)

review_title: Purdue is a good place to work, but does not reward hard work or achievement outside of the Academy
job_title: Data Manager in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
Decent benefits, though they were better a few years ago.
Fair amount of opportunity to advance, but depends on your experience and line of work
Positive changes coming from President Daniels that are long overdue
Worklife balance is excellent in most areas
cons:
Hard work is sometimes rewarded with extra work for others slacking off
No real incentive to perform unless to get a different job - many have found a soft spot and have continued in the same position for many years with little to no concern for the job
It is not uncommon to find people working simply for the benefits
You won't make anything near what you'd make in industry
Lots of senior management and few have a clue what work is being done.

review_title: Shiny public image, not so shiny interior.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The working environment is calm and the vacations package is great!
cons: Vertical moves are very hard to obtain and the pay scale system set up to keep it that way. Most clerical and service staff are not paid a living wage. Be prepared to work to jobs just to make ends meet if you work here. Infinitesimal raises that range from 1%-3%. While this may seem normal 1% does not even cover the annual raise to the cost of living.  3% raises are based on you performing perfectly and as the supervisors like to say....nobody is perfect.

review_title: Corp culture issues. They don't take care of regular staff,    but Sr. admin well paid
job_title: Programmer Analyst in West Lafayette, IN
pros: International, intellectual environment, impressive research, low cost of living
cons: Once upon a time the low pay staff received was balanced by job security and  benefits. It was a great place to work and a family atmosphere. This is no longer the case. Expect to still see salaries about 20% less than market but staff expendable mindset today. After 25 yrs of exceptional service, considering cost of living, I made less at Purdue than I did starting as a new grad in 1988.

job_title: IT Support in West Lafayette, IN
pros: It is a good place to work. The people are a very nice and cooperative. My supervisor was very understanding and a fun guy. He would get pizzas for us just randomly and treat us. So people around you care about you. which rare to find in a work place.
cons: It is very difficult to find cons as honestly I loved working here. As I was a part time student employee I had almost no freedom for my scheduled. So very strict with time which is sometimes hard to adhere to.

review_title: I am a faculty member at Purdue University
job_title: Prof of Chemistry in West Lafayette, IN
pros: I've been very fairly treated for nearly 40 years. Very patient with me as I've varied my time commitment due to entrepreneurial activities.  The students are terrific to work with and we have a very collegial chemistry department of dedicated scholars and teachers. The flexibility of academia is fabulous, lots of independence, great to work with smart young people on important problems.  Leadership of current president Mitch Daniels is refreshing and open to experimentation.
cons: Large bureaucracies always have some challenges when on occasion the wrong person gets put in the wrong spot.  That happens, but down in the trenches at the department level one works around it.  Higher ed is challenged today on most fronts; funding research, affording tuition, convincing government on value and affordability. We will get through this.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Most students are amicable, intelligent, and gregarious. Professors and advisors have invaluable experience and life lessons to relay to you. You will learn much more than you ever thought you could and acquire experience akin to the kind you would get in a job. Most professors do not seek to control the students and give them ample freedom and latitude to do research.
cons: A well-rounded life is not encouraged enough. You actually feel like your entire life revolves around research and that every free moment you should be working on it. You can kiss your other goals goodbye or expect prolonged delays or slow progress.

review_title: Full of In-Fighting and political maneuvering
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hammond, IN
pros: Decent non-monetary benefits, short commute if you live in Hammond.
cons: Underpaid, since the merger of the two campuses, lots of in-fighting and political posturing that make for a toxic work environment. They treat you less like a human and more like pawn to be used in a grand game of chess. I've seen multiple people fired with no warning at all, only because one person had more political connections within the organization and wanted a larger 'piece' of the puzzle. Be prepared to work outside of normal work hours, especially if it's in the IS department.

job_title: Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Great research university! You are learning from the best in your field no matter what discipline you're in! Its also great to have all of the perks of being a student on campus, while also getting paid to study. Insurance is pretty inexpensive.
cons: You will have to work way more hours than what you are paid for. This is a reality for all graduate school. However, it is easy to feel burnt out when your always worried about money. The pay is enough to live on, but you definitely need to be thrifty.

review_title: Great place to work, near Chicago, plenty of parking, good benefits.
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Hammond, IN
pros: Collegial community that truly values cultural diversity. Provides low-cost parking in a relatively new, brightly-lit garage, as well as large surface lots. Great technology. Close to Chicago and Lake Michigan.  Encourages tenure-track and tenured faculty research, as well as undergraduate student research. Requires all undergraduates to complete two service learning courses.
cons: Not many good places to eat nearby, and the surrounding community is a bit depressed. Due to statewide budget cuts for Indiana state colleges, they have had to deal with budget cuts.  Pay is a bit low compared to other universities where I interviewed. Relies too heavily on adjunct faculty.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
-lots of accomplished and smart professors to learn from
-Good sequencing and microscopy facilities. Decent greenhouses/growth chambers.
-Lots of fields available for growing crops for research (corn, wheat, soybeans and more). This is great if you're doing research that requires planting a lot of plants.
cons:
-departments are somewhat self-contained. It can be difficult to obtain collaborations or discussions with people outside your department.
-Some departments don't offer rotations for first-year graduate students and this could lead to poor matches between PI and student. Think carefully before deciding on a graduate position with no rotations.

review_title: Former Graduate Student Having Trouble with Degree
job_title: Graduate Student in Hammond, IN
pros: One of the program professors does care about students' success in the graduate program. I liked how our graduate program had a project portfolio for each class (Taskstream).  Tuition cost at PNW was very affordable.
cons: Once you graduate from the program, the former program chair ignores you from then on. The former program chair misled students over the course of the program giving us false hope and reassurance. Graduate program did not prepare its graduates for real jobs. We were not exposed to e-Learning authoring tools which limit employability in the job market.

job_title: Academic in West Lafayette, IN
pros: good reputation, good infrastructure, big campus ample amount of collaborations, little commute
cons: petty bureaucracy, underutilization of resources, over-staffed, inefficient operations, the town lacks diversity, religious undercurrent being pervasive in backdoor business dealings, staff in charge of running the research and academic aspects of the university operations instead of the faculty. no space in child care and limited quality child care options outside campus. school system is ok, should do much better for a university town though. little town 'perks' such as a lousy mall or no decent grocery store (need to drive to Indy for such things). Make sure that your spouse's employment is arranged before accepting your job. They will tell you jobs are plenty, but in fact, they are not. There is a saturation of highly skilled post-graduate work force and scarcity of jobs...

job_title: in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Purdue University is a great place to work because Purdue prides itself on being at the cutting edge of technology and invests a lot of money in new technologies.  The new nanotechnology center at Purdue provides a lot of room for career growth at the University.  Due to this investment in technology there is a lot of outside research money coming into Purdue, providing for advanced equipment and interesting research topics.
cons: The compensation is low compared to comparable sized universities.  The location of Purdue University is another downside.  West Lafayette isn't exactly a cultural mecca, however it is only an hour drive to Indianapolis.  A plus to living in West Lafayette is that it has a low cost of living.

job_title: Adjunct in Hammond, IN
pros: For most, an easy commute, but that is likely to change soon.
cons: Within the past 5 years: Extreme disloyalty to long term "workhorse employees" with great evaluations and productivity - as in mass terminations with no regard to performance.  No support, inadequate infrastructure, no opportunities for involvement and advancement and active opposition for those who try to create them.  Top heavy and clueless administration goes against their own policies.  Most  decisions are top down, but  the attempts to coat it with a veneer of input from faculty are insulting lies.  E.G. recent merger with campus decided with NO faculty or student input - but "Hey, a contest to name the merged campuses" which will likely be disastrous for students and another imposition on underpaid faculty.  Politically and secretively appointed president of University.  Salaries are 25-50% below comparable institutions (except top administrators.)  Take a job outside academe rather than work here.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: covers cost of tuition, half off wife's tuition, usually far fewer than 20hrs work (even for a 20hr appointment). Working as a TA provides insight and opportunities to learn topics more thoroughly.
cons: Terrible part of the country. Possibly the worst. Definitely would not have come here if I had been fully informed. Police are inactive, people are ultra conservative, infrastructure is poor. Very poor. Human-feces poor. Construction projects are not conducted respectfully. They spill into streets, bike paths, and sidewalks. The city planners do nothing about this. The driving is embarrassing. The police are guilty of poor driving as well. The bus drivers are particularly inept.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The diverse working environment is a great way to learn how to interact with others from various backgrounds and ethnicities. The students were the ones who made my job fun every day. The Professors were very generous around holidays and celebrations, which was a great bonus! I adored working with almost every single person in my department.
cons: The upper management/department heads were what started the downhill slide of the particular department I worked in. Once a new Head was hired in, he began acting very unprofessionally. Then, those who were immediately beneath him started acting the same way. It just seemed to kind of trickle down from there, with others following his lead.

review_title: It's been good for the past 15 years
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The university continues to be a leader in the engineering, technology, and business communities.  Faculty and staff on the whole are happy to be here, and students get a top-flight education.
cons: The liberal arts often get the short end of the stick -- which goes against the idea of a "university".  Also, Mitch Daniels prioritizes the bottom line over the university's educational mission much more often than he should.

job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant Instructor in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Very helpful and enjoyable working experience. While the workload and compensation vary by department, the organization as a whole does a good job of making you feel appreciated and aware of available resources.
cons: The winter in the area is terrible, and living close to campus is more expensive, causing the commute to be troublesome. The liberal arts are viewed as less, as with most university settings, and compensation tends to be griped about as a result.

review_title: A great environment if you can handle the bureaucracy
job_title: Visiting Professor in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Purdue is a wonderful place to work and lies in one of the fastest growing cities in the U.S. with a very low cost of living. Employees are treated very fairly from the professors to the groundskeepers. Though the campus is large, it is like one big, close-knit family.
cons: If you are not hired on as a full-time professor, the limited-term lecturer position has a very low salary with minimal or no benefits. Since Purdue is a research university, a high value is placed on bringing in money through grants. Sometimes, it feels like more emphasis is put on bringing in money than providing an education to the students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Opportunity to work with talented people that really love what they do.  I have learned a lot and experienced a lot of things.  I have learned a lot about Particle Physics.
cons: Lots of work for very little compensation.  No real training for an actual job.  You are at the complete mercy of your Adviser for time off, graduation time, pay.  I feel that I was mislead in the opportunities that I would have after I graduate.  I get school payed for not because there is a lack of physics scientists, but because it is cheap labor.

review_title: Professional Staff can find better jobs elsewhere.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Decent benefits, relaxed atmosphere, and interesting projects.  Working with professors and students can be exciting and rewarding.  The work-life balance is excellent with minimal overtime and a generous vacation policy.
cons: Anyone other than tenured faculty are treated poorly.  Base salary is low for comparable industrial positions, but benefits used to make up the balance.  That is no longer the case.  Many professors consider staff to be little more than useful furniture.  Things that would get a person fired in industry are swept under the rug (if they are faculty).  There is ineffective and incompetent management at the Dean and Department Head levels.

review_title: Opportunities for personal and professional growth
job_title: Information Center, Peregrine Shuttle Driver in Hammond, IN
pros: Easy-going environment with the chance to work with people directly from the field.  Get advice and hands-on work with experiential learning opportunities. You can get great connections to help you excel in whatever career path you wish to pursue.
cons: A lot of departments do not properly communicate with others, leading to dead ends or misinformation.  Sometimes, a little bit of investigative work is required for doing seemingly simple tasks (like getting in touch with professors and departments who may have moved, etc.).

job_title: Administrative/Prof in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Job security is good. Nice campus. Health benefits are good. Retirement plan is generous.
cons: No dental plan included in medical benefits - optional plan is overpriced and not worth the money. Three year vesting period retirement plan is silly. Generally not a place where young professionals want to stay - opportunities for advancement usually require changing jobs and in some cases function. No preference given to internal candidates in 99% of cases. Functional over-specialization is rampant and counterproductive. Culture is bureaucratic, outdated and inflexible. IT organization is simply terrible - meaning their culture if focused on implementing rigid standards and keeping their cost at an absolute minimum, rather than working to maximize the value of IT investments and increase productivity and morale.

review_title: Good Learning Experience for Student Employees
job_title: Student Representative in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
They worked around my school schedule really well. Flexible. I learned a lot about how Purdue works and also all the resources (IT resources and otherwise) students and employees have through the university.

More than anything - I really learned how to maintain patience with very difficult customers and cases. Customer service skills will take you a long way!
cons:
When budget cuts took place, the expectations of student representatives increased dramatically. We were not prepared for the higher complexity of issues.

Also, there was little communication from student employees to managers. We were told to report to "senior" student reps who had little power to do anything other than talk about it.

job_title: Secretary in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Flexibility in jobs and ability to transfer within the university.  Ability to take classes and good opportunities for advancement.
cons: Used to be best place in the area to work.  Strong benefits and good raises - not so much with the current economic situation and the new president whose salary and retirement benefits are not affected.  Job security isn't a given anymore and we've gone 2 years without raises.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Most of the faculty that I encountered as a graduate assistant were invested in their students, classes were great, and my peers were wonderful.
cons: The university clearly doesn't value the social sciences all that much. Salary as a graduate student in the social sciences was very low, especially compared with the salary of people in agriculture, engineering, and "hard" sciences. It was impossible to afford housing, food, and other necessities without borrowing or using credit cards.

job_title: Business Manager in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The middle management staff and clerical staff are very good to work with. They pride themselves on the quality of their work.
cons: Upper management doesn't take the time to learn the process and the why's things were done like they were. They just want to make their mark and change a process or system. Then they don't either tell anyone they made the change or expect the lower level staffing to figure out how to make it work. They also assume that all the new technology will make life easier, when in reality it has made everyone's life more difficult.

review_title: Graduate Assistants at Purdue are paid well, but staff fees take a bite out of that salary.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Purdue has a decent reputation and good pay for their graduate assistants.  The benefits, once deciphered, are not bad either.
cons: Staff fees for each semester are a significant portion of graduate salaries.  All healthcare is required to be first sought at the purdue student health center, but the quality of care there is generally sub par.  If you  have an accident after hours, the insurance company puts the burden on you to prove that you are not covered by other insurance and to provide details of the accident.  This significantly delays the payment process.

job_title: Office Manager in Hammond, IN
pros: It varies greatly by department, but my hours are somewhat flexible.
cons: There is no internal mobility at PNW.  You will be offered a very low starting salary, and you will maintain that salary for the entirety of your time here.  "Merit increases" are never more than 2%, assuming they aren't in such a terrible budget deficit and you actually get one.  There are no written policies or procedures for nearly anything.  You can ask 6 different people how they accomplish the same task, and get 6 different answers--even from the processing business department!  It is frustrating to work somewhere that is so consistently reactive, rather than proactive.  Staff morale is very low because of the treatment they receive from faculty and senior leadership.  They are not valued or incentivized to improve so good employees leave and lazy employees stay.  The climate between the two "unified" campuses is still tense after more than a year of having been officially joined as one University.  Westville staff and faculty and Hammond staff and faculty do not work as a unified team, but rather, they look at each other as enemies.  It is exhausting.  Additionally, there is no training available for employees on any of the systems used by the University.  New employees are left to flounder helplessly, without any means to learn or improve.  In the 3 years I have worked here, they have NEVER offered any training on the main database used (Banner), the HR/Payroll system, or really anything else, for that matter.  Everything I know I had to glean from struggling and failing, and desperately pleading for help from other overworked employees who have since quit.

review_title: Has been a fulfilling experience, but difficult at times
job_title: Graduate Student in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Great working environment and the salary is about what a graduate student should earn.  The hardships obtaining a graduate degree vary by department and by the adviser chosen.  In my case, it has been very difficult the last few years, but it will be worth it when finished
cons: Salary could also be higher, but not by much.  Trying to find parking on campus is very bad when classes are in session.  The other major con is that graduate students are treated like students when we should be treated like employees since we work and teach classes.

job_title: Librarian in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The benefits were pretty good, comparable to other universities in the region, and it is a campus where there is always something interesting going on.  There was always an interesting speaker or an exhibition to take advantage of, which were additional perks to being a Purdue employee.
cons: Unfortunately I found little opportunity for career advancement, and a very snobbish attitude on the part of faculty.

review_title: Nice Place but currently has some funding issues
job_title: Graduate Student in Lafayette, IN
pros:
Good Intellectual Resources: professors, libraries, expertise in the area of chemical engineering
Helpful People: On the whole people are willing to take time to talk to you and help you out intellectually if you ask.
cons:
Current Funding Issues: The projects I was interested in (using algae for bio fuel production) were having some trouble getting funding and it is hard to get involved with a engineering project if you were not accepted as an engineer due to departmental barriers.

Direction Provided: If you want direction you have to ask or provide it yourself.

job_title: Catering Assistant Manager in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Retirement and medical benefits. In my area most people were positive and pleasant to work with
cons: Most people in other departments have a 'not my job' mentality. Work life balance was not good but I worked in a non academic role (like an outside business would run). No raises or very little (0.75%) annually even with very good reviews

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Great curriculum, well established alumni network, lots of career opportunity (if you're in the right majors and area of concentration though), low cost of living, overall nice people, diverse population (only in terms of nationality and ethnicity), simple and relaxed life style
cons: Could be little depressing for those who are used to urban setting, not so many things to do for fun (I guess this is why people here all work out so much and are built), depressing winter season mostly due to gray sky. Certainly if you look for it there are various things to do but just don't expect the kind of dynamics you feel in the big cities.

job_title: Graduate Student in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Very nice and honest people.  Generally speaking, the people are hardworking, courteous, and genuine.  The West Lafayette development committees have been doing a good job at expanding the local shops but unfortunately, it's mostly chains.
cons: Not much going on in Lafayette or West Lafayette.  It's a bit to far to get to the beach and skiing is non-existent - that is, unless you don't mind driving 3 hrs to get to what would be considered a "bunny hill" in Colorado.  Pollution is pretty bad and the Wabash river is pretty filthy - you're asked not to swim in it and definitely don't eat the fish you catch.

job_title: Senior Business Manager in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The Purdue University Lafayette is great.  Even a large campus there is better communication than at the Calumet.  I worked at the Calumet for more than 1 year and worked at Lafayette for more than 2 years.  The SAP system used for accounting is good.
cons: The lady in charge of accounting does not understand SAP or even accounting for that matter.  She believed in punishing people.  You were blamed for things without knowing in advance what you were supposed to do.  She was always in a meeting but never brought back any information to her ranks.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The surrounding community is small, but is close in proximity to Indianapolis. Consequently, cost of living is low. The West Lafayette School District is excellent, but housing within the district limits is significantly more expensive. You can work with some of the most intelligent people in a variety of fields.
cons: As a graduate student, pay is ridiculously low. Other graduate programs in similar cost of living areas pay 50% more. Long hours, much longer than the 20 hours per week you are being paid.

review_title: My experience has been preparatory for what I know to be the real world of academia.
job_title: Graduate Lecturer in Paris
pros:
The research and teaching facilities are above average.
The professors are some of the most prolific and intelligent in all of academia.
cons: The pay for graduate students is low in comparison to similar institutions with similar teaching and research facilities. Some of the international students are not properly screened for their ability to speak and write in English. This makes it difficult for them.

review_title: Nice place to work in the Indiana area
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulogne-Billancourt
pros: Large community of students, professors and researchers from multiple disciplines. The medical insurance coverage is one the best in the area. The programs in engineering are within the top-10 in the country. A large portion of my job can be done from home so I typically don't spend too much time in the lab. Managers are very flexible with respect to work hours as long as publications and experiment deadlines are met.
cons: At times the job can be stressing since we have to meet deadlines with respect to writing articles, submitting grant applications and experimental procedures. However, during the summer the waters are quiet.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Toulouse
pros: Everyone at Purdue is exceedingly nice, friendly, and helpful, and the overall culture is very positive and inclusive. My boss truly cared about me and my career advancement. The benefits (health insurance, paid time off, tuition stipend, etc.) were outstanding. As with many university jobs, there are many advantages to working/living in a college town.
cons: Salary was below average for my field and experience level, but the benefits and overall good atmosphere more than compensated for that.

job_title: Student Caller At Rallyline in Villejuif
pros:
-Flexible work schedule
-Great for resume no matter what your major is
-Able to meet new friends via fellow callers
-Calling alumni can be very rewarding or even beneficial towards your own future (I know a student who got a co-op and future job opportunity from an alumni he had talked to)
-One of the best paying jobs on campus for students
cons: Recently, there have been a lot of management changes and a lot of aspects of the job are changing. However, if you are a new hire, you probably won't notice any of that since you will only be trained on what is new.

job_title: Student Summer Utility Worker in Paris
pros: You get to make friends. I was fortunate to be in the team that received different duties every week and was not tied down to a routine. You get to eat lunch at the dinning courts for only $3 a meal for part of the summer. The work is not too difficult and you get paid a fair wage.
cons: The job was a temporary summer job and it does not continue throughout the school year. Some workers are quite negative and may influence you. Some people are very proud and have big egos, lazy, complain a lot and talk behind each other's back.

review_title: Purdue University provided a vast work experience and broad networking experiences.
job_title: Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Opportunity to meet with experts in your interested field. The ability to be flexible and work when it is most convenient and have meetings when it is most convenient. Excellent funding!
cons: Relaxed timelines made it seem like everything was in slow motion. When expensive items needed to be replaced in laboratory settings, it was difficult to go through the process to replace them.

job_title: Supervisor in West Lafayette, IN
pros: Some of the greatest entry level workers around. Those who promote up usually know the job and respect their subordinates. Friendly atmosphere.
cons: Good old boy system. Too many people are hired in and/or promoted because they know someone in management. Upper management does not support the entry level workers. Human Resources is a joke and does not look into matters.

job_title: Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN

cons: Collaboration between research groups (including the sharing of facilities) could be better.  Work environments vary widely depending on your advisor.  Some groups have a very laid back atmosphere, while some have a strict schedule and responsibilities.

review_title: Director- awful from the start-run away from HHS
job_title: Assistant Director in West Lafayette, IN
pros: None! None none . Would give zero stars if it would let me. No purdue pride here
cons: Management is awful! Bullies abound. If you are young and look busy and act cute you will get further than if you are older and actually do the job.  I was told how to fill out my annual evaluation and to remove some things so that HR and higher supervisors would not see the bullying that goes on at HHS

review_title: Purdue is a very well organized, welcoming workplace.

The atmosphere was very professional, yet friendly. And with many different systems in place, it was a well organized workplace. This campus really values cultural diversity.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Lafayette, IN

That's not impossible, but a lot of projects get bogged down in lots of review, discussion, and indecision. Sometimes great ideas die in committee or a single meeting. review_title: This was my least favorite job I've ever had... underpaid and completely exploited.

review_title: I was a graduate student in Analytical Chemistry

review_title: Amazing place to work while in school
job_title: Student Simulation Programmer in West Lafayette, IN
pros:
- Extremely flexible hours, management is super understanding if you need to rework hours due to school, assignments or burnout. Mostly flat hierarchy which also promotes communication.
- Coworkers are super friendly and everyone cares about each other. Employees will often grab lunch together, hang out after work or sometimes schedule after work events (such as gaming sessions on the hundreds of thousands dollar multi screen panel or tabletop games).
- Location is in the PMU and is super convenient for grabbing food or heading to work, especially if you live close to campus.
- Lots of amazing and accepting coworkers that are happy to mentor and help you grow.
- Facility contains tons of great resources for you to use (3D printers, all sorts of VR/AR devices and peripherals).
- Getting to work with lots of different clients in various types of applications (games, simulations, animations, etc.) is incredibly satisfying and a great opportunity for networking.
- Generally insulated from the rest of ITAP, for better or worse (but generally for the better).
- Employees get to develop relationships with their clients, maintain ownership over their projects, and subsequently build their portfolios. A little leeway in setting deadlines, depending on the client.
cons:
- Student job pays student prices, undergraduates start at $11/hr with 50 cent raises per year, grads start higher.
- Higher turnover of undergraduate students due to the nature of things, this generally doesn't impact you in a bad way unless you're stuck with some legacy work on an old project.
- Students often get to know their clients very well, which is a plus until certain clients begin to become unmanageable. Management generally keeps this under control very well.
- Generally not very much crunch time (since deadlines are a joint agreement), but occurs sometimes and can sometimes overlap with school crunch times like around finals. Clients are generally pretty accepting since they know that you're students.

job_title: Accounting Clerk in Hammond, IN
pros: They have a work life program and offer family health insurance coverage.  Both of these things are due to the main campus.  The Lafayette Campus is very professional.
cons: Senior management does not respect the staff.  Some of the AVC level at the Calumet Campus lack the necessary training to hold their jobs and are simply there because they knew someone at some point.  After a while, the AVC was able to find a lower level employee to do their job, yet maintain their own status.  Yelling, name calling, fist banging and finger pointing are part of the daily routine, sad to say.

review_title: Computer Consultant at Purdue University. Check paper, printers. General security of the computer labs.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN

review_title: Purdue University Electrical and Computer Engineering
job_title: Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The life in west lafayette is very peaceful. And Purdue University is a very good Engineering university. The Electrical and Computer Engineering, where I worked as a research assistant, has a lot of cuting-edge engineering research. It's very interesting and we could also learn a lot of engineering skills and develop the ability to solve complicated engineering problem.
cons: The work load is large as for an Phd student. If you want to have good research results, you probably should work 50+ hours per week and additionally you will take class at the same time.

review_title: Fun job, but you only get about 5 hours per week
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The work is very easy.  I just have to show up to lab once a week and help students with questions.  It's enjoyable if you like to watch students learn.  Getting to talk to graduate TAs is also fun.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lafayette, IN
pros:
- Completely depends on the field, supervisor, and peers you have, because different research groups are typically completely independent. 
- In my case, the field is well-funded with many opportunities in fluid mechanics and control systems.
- The supervisor is sometimes difficult to work with, but we have a functional relationship.
- Compared to graduate RAs at most schools, I think the work-life balance here is generally better.
cons:
- Course exams are rapidly forcing good researchers out of the engineering program, because of the importance of GPAs in hiring. These researchers are being replaced with good test-takers. In my experience, there is very little overlap between these two groups of people. 
- Why is this so? Think about the concept of a good test-taker. This person has the ability to memorize large amounts of information, and reproduce it accurately in a span of 1 hour 15 minutes or less. 
- Now think about the concept of a good researcher. This person has the ability to creatively combine new ideas together with existing ideas from reference materials. A typical research project last months or even years. 
- The ability to memorize large amounts of data is generally not applicable in research, because reference materials are always available. 
- Skills like fast handwriting and fast memory response are likewise not meaningful in the context of a 2 or 3 year research project. 
- So it is unfortunate that Purdue (and many other schools) allows their faculty to continue to evaluate students in such a rushed, haphazard manner. 
- Obviously, evaluation based on semester-long projects is not a sufficient solution, because there is no control over who is actually doing the work. Same argument applies to homework. 
- A compromise is to simply allow more time for exams. Perhaps 3-4 hours. This cannot be done during the allotted lecture hour, so some schools have transitioned to giving exams in specialized testing centers. Students can go to the center when their schedules permit, and test proctors monitor them during the exam. 
- Also, to avoid rewarding memorization, non-electronic reference materials should be allowed during exams. 
- Everyone wins with this approach.  Professors don't need to sacrifice class days for exams. Students can be evaluated based on their knowledge (and even creativity), rather than speed. Students don't need to sacrifice several days of research time to memorize information or problem-solving approaches before exams.

job_title: Business Services in West Lafayette, IN
pros: The department I work in is welcoming with a number of very nice people.  I've made some very good friends there.  The grounds are immaculately kept and the animal science department has a meat market with good products.  Many opportunities to expand your knowledge about almost anything and learn about people and cultures from around the world. There is a certain amount of flexibility depending on which department/position you work in.  And I'm thankful to have a job in this low career potential geographical area.
cons: I'm sure this is true across the country, but coming from corporate America, I was surprised at how stressful it is to work in academia.  My role is one of gate keeper -- keeping the professors within the grant rules and the finances in order.  I supervise several business office staff.  When I first started working at Purdue in this role, I asked my supervisor if it was like a union shop.  Everyone had the list of what they do, and that was all they would do unless specifically TOLD to do something additional.  Training is poor.  The mantra I have heard is you either sink or swim here, and you don't want to sink.  So if you aren't the type of person who will go out on your own and dig for answers, you won't function well here.  The additional hook on that one is that you may speak to five different people and get five different answers.  (Did I mention training is poor?)  I have also experienced a condescending attitude, not on the part of professors as much as on the part of a number of long time staff members.  Plenty of people are lovely and willing to help.  Many others are not.  Business office protocol and process changes almost daily.  Often without notice, often without regard to the people doing the real work and what their customers expect/demand.  Benefits are just okay.  The pay is not commiserate with work load in this particular role or comparable to similar positions in corporate America.  Raises are minuscule to the point of being insulting.

review_title: Quality learning experience and vast support from colleagues and faculty members.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in West Lafayette, IN

review_title: Working towards a Ph.D. at Purdue
job_title: Graduate Student in West Lafayette, IN

review_title: Satisfactory exposure and experience in a diverse community.

job_title: Research Assistant in West Lafayette, IN

This lab is FDA regulated
